title: Redis - Overview
description:
This dashboard provides a high-level overview of key Redis metrics to help you monitor your Redis primary's performance and manage your Redis instance.

For more information, see:

- Our [official Redis documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/redisdb/)

Or our 3-part series blog post:

- Part 1: [How to monitor Redis performance metrics](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/how-to-monitor-redis-performance-metrics/) 
- Part 2: [Collecting Redis metrics](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/how-to-collect-redis-metrics/)
- Part 3: [Monitoring Redis with Datadog](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-redis-using-datadog/) (cloned)

definition.content:
This dashboard shows latency information and slow query counts that summarize your Redis master's performance, as well as memory metrics to help you manage your Redis instance.

##### [Official Datadog Redis documentation ↗](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/redisdb/)

**Our 3-part blog series**


[How to monitor Redis performance metrics ↗](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/how-to-monitor-redis-performance-metrics/)

[Collecting Redis metrics ↗](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/how-to-collect-redis-metrics/)

[Monitoring Redis with Datadog ↗](https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/monitor-redis-using-datadog/)

This metric is only available when the connection between the primary and its replica has been lost. Ideally, this value should never exceed zero—the primary and the replica should be in constant communication to ensure the replica is not serving stale data.

formulas.alias: Latency of the redis INFO command

definition.content: Latency measures the **time between a client request and the server response**, and monitoring it enables you to detect changes in Redis performance. The single-threaded nature of Redis means that a long response time for one request increases the latency for all subsequent requests, leading to serious bottlenecks.

Memory usage is a crucial performance factor. If `used_memory > total available system memory`, the OS will begin swapping old/unused sections of memory and writing them to disk. Writing or reading from disk is up to 100,000 times slower than writing or reading from memory (0.1 µs for memory vs. 10 ms for disk).

formulas.alias: Keys evicted due to the maxmemory limit

definition.content: Redis has 10,000 client connections available by default, but you can adjust the maximum number of connections with the `maxclient` directive in redis.conf. New connection attempts will be refused if your Redis instance is currently at its maximum number of connections.

formulas.alias: Connections waiting on a blocking call

definition.content:
Monitoring key length helps surface unexpectedly large or growing data structures (lists, sets, hashes, sorted sets), which can drive memory usage and cause performance issues. 

Enable in Agent's `redisdb.yaml` with the `keys` option.
